reviewText: If you want a series about Roman history, one can watch HBO's Rome (a very fine TV show). If you want to see a trashy and outrageously entertaining TV show with nonstop gore and nudity (both male and female) as well as graphic sex, Spartacus (very loosely based on the history of Ancient Rome's slave gladiator turned rebel leader) should be the choice.Supposedly, TV shows are by necessity tamer than movies, yet I haven't seen any movie as consistently graphic about sex and violence as Spartacus. Suffice to say that almost everybody in the large cast of mostly muscular men and gorgeous women, gets naked in the series at some point. Episode 9 in particular - subtly called "Whore" - is a highlight in that regard.A bit slow to start (I struggled with episode 1, but get hooked after episode 2), this admittedly not for all tastes series, was filmed in New Zealand with a mostly Australian and Kiwi cast. Its striking visual style can be compared with 300 (the gladiator's trainer, the great Peter Mensah, had a small role in that movie). The show is finely led in the titular role by Andy Whitfield (unfortunately he died of cancer after the first season, and was replaced by another actor in the following season). Yet, even if most of the cast is great, the best performance to me is by John Hannah as the devious Batiatus, the owner of the Gladiator's school. Hannah, whose background has been mostly on British comedies, excels here. While he initially seems to lack the toughness one supposes a master of a gladiator's school should have, he is eventually seen as a charming yet also very cruel and cunning man. Also remarkable are the performances of Manu Bennett as the knucklehead (but eventually noble) gladiator Crixus, Viva Bianca as the gorgeous but scheming Ilythia, and Nick Tarabay as Batiatus slimy aide, Ashur.

reviewText: First, a disclaimer. I don't get TV reception. I watched this show over Netflix. Thank you Starz and Netflix for making this available to those of us who do not get TV reception.The show is based on historical fact, but above all it is entertainment. And what entertainment it is!Spartacus: Blood and Sand is brought to you by the Xena dream team with Sam Raimi, Rob Tapert as producers and starring Lucy Lawless. John Hannah is the only other well-known actor. Andy Whitfield, Manu Bennet and Viva Bianca are all newcomers. Whether they are veterans or newcomers, this is a terrific ensemble cast. The writing, overseen by Stephen de Knight (also a producer), is dynamic, poetic, and brilliant. The first two episodes were directed by Rick Jacobson with other episodes directed by Michael Hurst, both from Xena and Hercules. Other directors fill in the rest of the season. Although Michael Hurst stands out as the best director, there wasn't a dud among them.The entire show is shot on a soundstage against a green screen. The CGI is occasionally not up to snuff, but the content of the show overcomes any deficit in the CGI department. The first two episodes, which established back story for Spartacus, were probably the weakest of the series. By episode three, when Lucretia and Batiatus (Lucy Lawless and John Hannah) make their appearance, things start rolling. Viva Bianca creates the character Ilithyia, the woman you love to hate. The scenes between Lawless and Bianca are fabulous and get better as the series progresses.There is something for everyone: blood, violence, sex, nudity and most of all intrigue. I highly recommend the show, this is the best thing on TV, and possibly the best thing ever on TV. You will laugh, you will cry, and you will beg for more when you hit episode 13.

reviewText: This is just abysmally LCD (lowest common denominator) tripe. By all means, rent HBO's Rome, which has superior acting, scriptwriting, historical accuracy. The fighting scenes are just gratuitous carnage, no momentum or suspense whatsoever. At least in Alexander or Troy, though the fighting techniques were highly stylized and even unbelievable, at least there was a context that allowed for willing suspension of disbelief. Achilles, for instance, is a demigod, so seeing him fly through the air and perform impossible acrobatics was allowable. The action scenes in this Spartacus debacle are jus plain risible, conjuring up Monty Python at it's most ludicrously sublime "Tennis, Anyone?" . reviewText: Recently, while watching a movie, a trailer for a different film called my attention. It had almost the same awesome production design and photography of "300," a picture that I truly enjoyed. It turned out that the trailer was not about a film; rather, it was about a TV original series. And what a find it was! "Spartacus - Blood and Sand, the Complete First Season" is what grandiose and majestic entertainment is all about.The DVD set features all thirteen episodes from the first season, each one approximately fifty minutes long. It properly begins from the beginning, when we first meet Spartacus (not his name at the time), inside a dirty cell, just before he goes out and fight for his life as a gladiator in front of thousands of people that enjoy the killing and dismembering of other human beings. While sitting alone, he begins remembering the conditions that took him there in first place. We are taken back to those happy years, when he enjoyed the love of his wife Sura (Erin Cummings), but his town was always in constant danger from the enemy. Unwillingly, his people - The Thracian -- form an alliance with the Romans, who also happen to share the same enemy (the Getae). Unfortunately, the Romans betray their allies, and Spartacus and his wife are separated, both becoming slaves. Spartacus is sent to Capua, in Italy, where he is ordered to be slaughtered in the gladiator arena. However, he survives and quickly becomes a commodity in the gladiator market.  Although still a slave, he apparently has the opportunity of getting his freedom back one day, depending on his success as a gladiator.Spartacus is then sent to a ludus, a place where gladiators are trained, owned by the manipulative and brutal Batiatus (John Hannah), who prides himself of having the best gladiators in Capua. His right-hand man, also a slave, is Doctore (Peter Mensah), an impressive African and ex-gladiator who is in charge of training. Spartacus reluctantly accepts to become a gladiator, but accepts after Batiatus promises him to reunite him with his wife. From then on, seeing his wife again is Spartacus' main motivation in life. What follows, then, is the history of Spartacus as a gladiator and all the things that he has to endure to survive. Each episode is unique, in which new characters are added or eliminated, and some we get to know very well. There are friendships and envies, love and lust, trust and backstabbing -- the entire package that provides for a good series."Spartacus - Blood and Sand, the Complete First Season" is meant to introduce us to the Spartacus made famous on film by Kirk Douglas, and the series focuses on his early, formative years, and how he became a leader in the uprising of the slaves against the Roman Empire. But, contrary to the movie version, this series is crude and very much realistic, as well as for mature audiences, with as much blood as you care to see, with plenty nudity and sexual situations, just the way it was during those gruesome years. At the same time, we learn history the hard way. Andy Whitfield shines as Spartacus, as well as the rest of the formidable cast, including Manu Bennett, Lucy Lawless and Nick E. Tarabay. It's all great, addictive entertainment. The DVD set is loaded with extras, like audio commentaries, behind-the-scenes, gladiator boot camps, and much, much more. (USA, 2010, color, 692 mins).Reviewed on September 29, 2010 exclusively by Eric Gonzalez for [...]

reviewText: I know I will get flamed or ridiculed for this opinion, but Spartacus: Blood and Sand is probably the better and more historically accurate version that is the legend of Spartacus. Yes, the violence is over the top with the 300ish style. Yes, the sex is VERY over the top and would be considered more pornographic than anything released theatrically (especially more so than USA director cuts). But when it boils down to a depiction about the savagery of gladiators and the outlandish lifestyle of the Roman empire, this show does nail it. Nothing is held back and the viewer needs to have an open mind when watching Blood and Sand. However, anybody easily offended by bodily mutilation and sexual display NEED to stay away.As I have informed many people about this show, the first episode is the most difficult to get by. It's painfully awful cheesy. Then almost immediately during the second episode, the show gets better. After the 5th, it becomes a very enticing historical drama. The life of the Roman gladiator is the real treat as you watch Spartacus forget his past and become a Legend in the Capua Arena. In my opinion, the best part of this TV series is that this story is more accurate than the famous 1960 film. If one were to watch this entirely, then go and do quick research, the viewer would understand that the writers did in fact do their research, even though still very dramatized.I would prefer nothing else but to own a Blu-ray release of this series. Anything below 720p for this show would never be enough to display the wonderful performances of the actors and the brilliant cinematography. Even though I watched this on Netflix, this is on my Amazon wish list to own very soon. It is of course a sad note to the late Andy Whitfield. Spartacus: Blood and Sand is officially his acting legacy. But what he left is an unforgettable performance and a story of Spartacus that made me anticipate the next series: Vengeance, with high anticipation. Entertainment fans of historical dramas particularly of the Roman Empire should not scoff or miss this.

reviewText: Yes, this is a VERY bloody show. Yes, there is a lot of frank, graphic, sexual scenes. Yes, the video editing is over the top in many places, in a style that seems a cross between Sin City and 300. And no, there will not be lengthy discussions regarding Aristotle or Plato. Because of all these things, my wife and I LOVED Season 1 of Spartacus and cannot wait for Season 2.Look - I wasn't around 2,000 years ago, but much of the treatment of the Gladiators/slaves seems to be consistent with what I have learned about historical Rome. I feel good about humanity's progress that some reviewers find the blood and gore disturbing. I remember when HBO began the series Rome. I remember many people criticizing that series because it was more violent and sexually oriented than classic movies from previous decades about the Roman Empire. My response at the time was that the Romans were far more 'barbaric' in their day to day lives than audiences of previous decades were ready to see on the big screen, or censors would allow Americans to see. People eventually came to see HBO's Rome as the most realistic portrayal of Roman culture to date. I believe the same logic applies to Spartacus.I also appreciated the slow-motion, graphic novel, style of video editing. I certainly prefer it to old-school film fight scenes where someone is stabbed through with a sword, yet there is no visible blood.Regarding the dialog, I would have been VERY upset if uneducated slaves spoke like poets. I do not watch football for the graceful athleticism, but for the pounding gladiatorial action. When I want to see graceful athleticism, I go to see dancers on the stage.In short, there is a purpose for everything under the sun. If you like action, aggression, reasonably accurate historical portrayals, stylistic film editing and pithy one liners, you will like this series.

reviewText: I enjoy a good toga drama along the lines ofGladiator (Widescreen Edition), the HBO SeriesRome: The Complete Seriesor the originalSpartacusfilm starring Kirk Douglas.  When I heard about Starz production of "Spartacus: Blood and Sand", I will admit to a little excitement--after all it is not every day that I get to see handsome buff men running around in next to no clothing.  Sadly, "Spartacus: Blood & Sand" does not deliver the intellectual buzz along with the soft porn for which many Premier cable channel series have incorporated as trademark.<Update: April 23, 2010  With regard to the above comment--the first episode of this serial drama was pretty copycat300 (Widescreen Edition)--and not in a good way--the sex seemed soft-porny and not entirely necessary as some of the gruesome battle scenes with slow motion graphic comic style blood splatters that actually drip down the lens of the cameras as they film.  As the series unfolds and the different threads woven throughout the storyline revealed, there are indeed still many scenes depicting the sexual liberalness of the Roman family nucleus which includes the complete disregard for the mental/ethical well-being of their slaves that were used to the hilt for these themed activities and the splatter-day events featured in the arenas that were as popular and everyday as our NFL weekends. However, as cartoony and graphic-novel-y as these scenes may be they are better integrated into the plot--or perhaps it is just that I have become immune to the gore and not as overwhelmed by the random sex.>The story line offers nothing new:  A politically-minded Roman literally throws his newly allied Thracian villagers to the barbarian wolves.  When Spartacus & Co. realize that the Roman has no intention of protecting their homes, they desert, hurrying back to their villages to head off the hoard of painted tribesmen intent on burnt offerings. Of course, the crafty Roman doubles back and collects the wayward Thracians and then parades them in chains to Capua, the home of his distinguished father-in-law.  Games in the arena are to be provided for the lulling of the masses and the captured Thracians are to be pitted against some of the Empire's most seasoned champions.  In an unintentional parody of the "Are You Not Entertained?" sequence in Ridley Scott's 'Gladiator,' Spartacus slaughters the group of professionals with some deft moves pumped up with unbelievable and unwarranted gore that nearly splashes in the viewer's eyes.  And a legend is born . . .You would think that all that blood, hints of political intrigue and action would have the audience sitting on the edge of its seats.  However, instead of tantalizing its viewers, Spartacus: Blood & Sand petrifies them into yawning pillars of sand and not due to looking back at the more than abundant supply of sumptuous body parts including full frontals bent in sexual contortions right out of an illustrated guide of the Karma Sutra. Less is more definitely applies here especially with regard to lascivious language that seems to be the order of the day between husbands and wives, battle comrades and dueling politicians.Yuck!  The one hour that I watched had me grimacing as buckets of blood slashed and splattered out of slit chests, backs and necks.  Most gruesome was the gladiator slithering away on his stomach after his legs had been hacked off his body.  UGH!  Compliment all this gore with love scenes that could be shown at a bachelor party and you have a full spectrum of the yin and the yang that completely contradicts the idea of balance and good taste on any level.Bottom line?  I simply was not entertained by Spartacus: Blood and Sand.  I don't recommend it.<Update April 23, 2010--Okay, as this series unfolds, there is much more to say positively about it.  The characters are well drawn out despite the sex--which when seen from the perspective of a gladiator in his cell makes sense--and the blood which looks almost comedic in a graphic comic NR for Mature Audiences type of way.  The plot is an interesting take on the film of the same name as this first series depicts only Spartacus's time as a slave of the ludus meaning there is much more to come, more corrupt characters to meet and more intrigue to wade through as some of the wastrels of the first season actually made it through the blood and gore of the last ten minutes of the finale. Ladies, these gladiators are hot--Guys, the slave girls provide an equal amount of eye candy--something for everyone. reviewText: This is the single most historically accurate film / series on the Roman empire I have ever seen.  It becomes immediately obvious that the series was heavily inspired byGladiator (Widescreen Edition)and300 (Widescreen Edition).  Of course, there is certainly nothing wrong w/that as both of these films were quite well done.There are too many tidbits of historical accuracy to mention, but I will point out a few.  In the arena sequences, the gladiators are shown with their sword arms being padded.  This is true to form as the Romans loathed a quick bout.  The last thing they wanted to see was a gladiator with his sword arm disabled as he would not be able to fight back against his adversary.Also, the gladiators did collect their sweat, mostly for wealthy Roman matrons who wanted to use it to remove wrinkles & improve their  health.  One of the gladiators is a freeman instead of a slave.  This has historical veracity as well as occasionally people in dire financial straits would voluntarily become gladiators and bet on themselves to get out of debt.Not a whole lot is known about the historical Spartacus, other than the fact that he was a Thracian slave who was trained to be a gladiator at a gladiatorial school (known as a ludus) in the Roman city of Capua.  This allows the writers a great deal of leeway to ad-lib on history.  The result is a remarkable series which takes its time to slowly unfurl the storyline.For a series that stars a bunch of buffed up dudes, the acting is pretty darn good.  As a matter of fact, it's downright exceptional.  Andy Whitfield has a fabulous screen presence and none of the actors portraying gladiators come across as big dumb oafs (thankfully they didn't cast the bland John Cena for the series!).  As was the case for300 (Widescreen Edition), the actors go through a month long boot camp to become ripped.SPARTACUS scores very high on the skin-o-meter, which is always a good thing. Also, the gladiator bouts are not for the squeamish.  It's good to see that Lucy Lawless has no qualms about nudity, now that her XENA days are over.  The series does a terrific job of really taking us inside the ludus with all of its brutality & debauchery.This is a series that is bound to be appealing to both men & women.  Men will love it due to all of the action & nudity, while women will be drawn to all of the muscle-bound jocks.  For those who are interested in a fictional account of a female gladiator ludus, I would highly recommendGladiatrix.  If Roman history is your gig, then this series is most assuredly for you!

reviewText: WARNING:This movie has intense depictions of graphic violence, language, sexuality, and nudity.  It is recommended for a mature audience (ages 18 and older).INTROThis gripping tale of Spartacus, the legendary 1st century Gladiator during the rule of Rome is a spectacular series featured on Starz.  The story develops with our hero, a Thracian warrior, enlisted by the Romans to fight against the Getae.  Andy Whitfield plays the warrior who leads a mutiny against the legion's leader, Claudius Glaber.  Upon being captured, his wife is sold into slavery while Thracian warrior is sentenced to die in the arena against 4 gladiators.  We battles the gladiators and wins with the crowds cheering for his victory.  The scene is a dynamic and rather gory display of violence, taken to the highest level.  The sheer brutality depicted in the finale of the 1st episode and demonstrated throughout the subsequent episodes is a trademark of the entire miniseries.  Taken in by Lentulus Batiatus (who inherited a school of Gladiators from his father), he names the warrior Spartacus, after a Thracian King.  It is the transformation over the course of the series whereby Spartacus is trained from Warrior to Gladiator.  Doctore (played by Peter Mensah, who played the messenger in 300), a former gladiator, trains the group of men in a rigid and disciplined manner.THE STORYThe quest for Spartacus' freedom is what motivates him to continue to fight, in alliance with his "Master" Batiatus.  Batiatus' wife battles infertility and is in support of her husband, every step of the way - while pleasing herself with the school's prime fighter, Crixus, in various rendevous with him.The story and character development help weave the story of this Gladiator who goes on to lead a slave uprising against the Romans.  As the story progresses, we see the alliance that Spartacus has made with his Dominus, Batiatus.  Multiple stories are intertwined as the characters progress throughout the series.  Does Lucretia continue her affairs with Crixus to the end?  How about Crixus' fascination with Naevia, the slave closest to Lucretia?  The brotherhood between Spartacus and Batiatus show the human side of Spartacus, as they train together.  The conniving Ashur is a snakelike metaphor who interweaves his life between the training grounds and the city, doing his will for Batiatus.  The sly Ilithyia befriends Lucretia but how does their friendship endure through the plight of Batiatus' thirst for power in Capua.  Solonius the ever suave opponent of Batiatus frequently vies for Lucretia's attention while plotting with Ashur, in the darkness.  Does Sura reunite with her Spartacus?  Will Crixus regain the glory of "Champion of Capua", and how does Doctore aid in Crixus' ascent back to the crowds' favor?  Each episode is compelling, and the acting is superb.  The odd references to sexuality made by Batiatus' experiences with getting the lower hand in many events is somewhat puzzling, and I hope that the Blu-ray version gives insight to the history between Batiatus and Solonius.  The true love/hate relationship we have for Batiatus as an underachieving owner of a Ludis, while plotting to gain money and power behind the scenes, shows a dynamic character portrayed by John Hannah (Best known from The Mummy Series).  Many of the key characters are British or from New Zealand.  Viva Blanca who plays Ilithyia is a beautiful actress that we just love to hate.DETAILSThe movie is in the same vein (sorry, in this case, artery) as 300 and the Gladiator, but makes those movies look tame in comparison.Cinematography is left to rendered landscapes and simple sets with emphasis in the Villa, Ludis and town.  The visuals are well done and the heroes and heroines are detailed with authentic appearing costumes, blood, scars and physiques (feminine and masculine) in a consistent form.  Language of the actors is more a reflection of their native tongue, I surmise, versus the actual accents by which the Romans, Gauls and Thracians spoke.Each episode has stunning fight scenes in the arenas or at the Batiatus villa with vicious brutality, gore and violence.  The violence is so extreme, at times, that other movies and shows pale in the comparison from the liters of blood that is spilled from the characters.  Almost every episode has scenes of sexuality and nudity.The last episode is an amazing, fast-paced and graphically gory conclusion to one of the best mini-series that I have ever watched on cable television.CONCLUSIONThis movie is a definite must see and must have for your Blu-ray collection.  I have pre-ordered it and it will become part of the Pantheon of "Man Movie Night"!!!

reviewText: As a woman who loves history, especially ancient civilizations, and who enjoyed the movie 300 for that reason and, well... *ahem* other attractions, when I heard about this series on cable I was admittedly curious.I have never purchased any TV series before so I took the plunge with this one and while I thoroughly enjoyed it, I must admit to having been taken aback in the first episode by the nudity and the perpetualy use of particularly ugly profanity.However, a funny thing happened on the way to maxing out my blushing fuse, I actually stopped noticing the nudity and the majority of the foul language.  Believe me, I'm no prude by any stretch of the imagination, but I do have a limit to how many times I care to hear four letter words that start with F and C before it becomes downright absurd.The way the series is filmed is truly captivating, the blending of sets and then the CGI effects was impressive and effective.  The wardrobe for the ladies was just gorgeous as was the period jewelry that they wore, and the attire for the men was also equally impressive, though the gladiators wore loin cloths and little else, and THAT was quite all right.The nudity and foul language were integral to the story being told, and it was told so well that you stopped noticing the bare bits bobbing about before you, and in most cases, the men and women who were nude looked very good in that state of undress.  In the fighting and training sequences, there is some viscerally intense scenes where body parts are removed from the whole and there is alot of stylized bleeding going on, but it is obvious that that part is not real.The dialogue is fast paced and smartly written.  The plots, subplots and tertiary characters are all interesting and you feel like you're watching a chess game being played as everyone moves and positions themselves to advantage so that they'll be the winner in the end.And in the center of it all is Spartacus, believably played by the late Andy Whitfield.  I was so sorry to hear of his passing and I watched the series again after I learned of his death, finding his performance to be spot on and noble.  Spartacus is a man who makes war and sheds blood but only because he must to survive, before and after the betrayal at the hands of the lying Legatus.He fights so that he can find his wife who was sold into slavery at the time he was also sold as a slave.  He fights to earn coin so he can pay to buy her freedom once she's found and brought to to the household of the Dominus who keeps and trains him to fight for the crowds.  And when his wife is killed, he continues to fight to honor a man who has none, the Dominus who betrayed him and arranged for his wife's murder while lying to Spartacus' face the entire time, always moving on that chessboard to best advantage.  He fights to pay for his only friend's gambling debts and when he dies in so useless a way, he continues to fight to pay to take care of his friend's widow and young son.He's a barbarian who is more noble and civilized than the so called high born Roman nobles who use and abuse the gladiators and those of lesser social standing.It is a riveting series and a feast for the eyes in more ways than one, the plotting and twists keeping you on the edge wanting more.Unfortunately, Andy Whitfield will not be able to provide since he left us at such a young age, but his work remains and it was a body of work to be proud of.This series is well worth the investment and one of those guilty pleasures that only whets your appetite for the next season to begin.

reviewText: Let me make this very clear. If you are at all squeamish, easily offended by language or sexual situations, or possessed of tender sensibilities, this is not the series for you. Gratuitious and horrific blood and violence, copious, varied, and explicit sex, a large amount of very colourful language (I had to steel my sensibilities here myself; I don't know anybody who uses that kind of language so fluently), and an almost cartoonish graphic-novel approach to Roman history, would tend to weed out quite a few viewers. This is many leagues from "I, Claudius" - but, on the other hand, you shouldn't watch this series expecting it to be. For those who are willing to forego judgment because of any of the above-listed elements, this series is a huge romp.I went into the viewing of this a relative novice; I don't subscribe to any premium channels, and aside from a little bit of Showtime and HBO enjoyed elsewhere, all I expected was a sort of cheesy rehashing of an old historical tale with low production values. Starz quite vindicated itself with the quality of filming and the great acting by the largely-unknown cast. From the first spurt of blood panned in slow motion across the screen, you know the predominant color in the film will be red; the red of blood, the red of Lucretia's (Lucy Lawless, vamping it up shamelessly) hair, the brown-red of the mountain villa where most of the action takes place.The man we come to know as Spartacus (we are never told his real name), a Thracian little better than a barbarian, is tapped by the local Roman legate to assist in the eradication of an even-more-barbaric tribe that is making a nuisance of itself in the area near Capua, part of the Roman Empire. Events transpire wherein 'Spartacus', the nominal leader of this Thracian band, abandons the Roman interest in favor of saving his own village, which he arrives too late to accomplish. In retribution for his perceived treason, the Roman legate enslaves both 'Spartacus' and his wife - both having escaped the enemy tribe - and the hero sees his wife carried off and himself installed in a remote ludus (gladiator training camp) after fighting free of intended destruction in the arena.The first season is a nonstop, fast-moving spin of battles, training, violent death, sex (mostly by the Roman ruling class), and the conniving of some very witchy ladies. There is also a plethora of bare bosoms, gorgeous physiques, full-frontal nudity of both sexes (yes, that's sensationalism, but then, there it is; and probably not far off the mark of actuality), and blood, blood, blood. The acting is, as has been said, exceptional; Andy Whitfield, as Spartacus, plays his role iron-jawed and full of pride and honor; Manu Bennett, as his arch-rival, plays his role with a wild-eyed craziness that I would be frightened of if I met him on the street. Craig Parker, the legate, (last seen as Haldur the Elf in LOTR), lends the proper amount of slimy superiority to his part, as does his abominable, easy-to-despise wife (Viva Bianca). Lucy Lawless shows she's lost nothing since Xena, Warrior Princess; she plays a more refined, older version of the same woman, surviving by her wits and yet vulnerable.The time period is just as the Roman Empire starts to implode; intrigues and gile are beginning to nibble away at the power of the Roman rule, and those greedy for more standing start to make political moves a bit beyond their grasp. As in chess, it's not the seasoned player that's the danger; it's the ones new to the game, who can introduce a twist unlooked-for. This series is full of sidesteps and plots. Bring an open mind and let yourself be sucked in, as I was.

reviewText: Probably spurred on by the popular television series ROME, SPARTACUS: BLOOD AND SAND premiered this weekend.  It is a mess. It seems as though actor Andy Whitfield would like to make us care about the slave turned hero, but given the lines he has to speak it is difficult not to just chuckle at his plight.  John Hannah and Lucy Lawless color the otherwise amateur cast. It makes one wonder why so much money was spent of such a lackluster series. But then, if it lasts as a series it may get better with some judicious re-editing.  Not for the faint of heart or those hoping for a newly conceived version of that grand old movie that started it all.  Grady Harp, January 10Addendum: April 10  After watching the entire season my opinion changed.  I did get to appreciate the characters more - especially Andy Whitfield and the other slaves gladiators.  There were some interesting little side stories and in general each show drove toward a good end.  The blood fest continued to be humorous and garrish but it fit the story.  The one aspect that seemed to never improve was the stilted dialogue, written as though someone were trying to imitate Latin.  And the use of expletives was more than likely unknown in Spartacus' time - though almost every spoken line had coarse terms in it.  Will this viewer watch it agin next season?  Yes, and we all wish Andy a speedy recovery!

reviewText: I'll concentrate mostly on the blu-ray disks than a movie review.  As an amateur of Roman history, I'm aware that few movies capture real Rome, its usually sanitized.  The HBO series 'Rome' captured wider elements of Roman life that was just as sexual and brutal as Spartacus.  However, Spartacus amplified it more, and focused on one man and his immediate surroundings.  Just as 'Saving Private Ryan' introduced audiences to a less sanitized version of WWII and its horrors, Spartacus does the same to an ancient Roman era.ProsThe video transfer is 5/5 superb, better than the broadcast version as its 1080p versus 1080i, and the difference shows.  The sound too, is 5/5, very crisp and clear.  If you liked the series, the blu-ray is a must.  The colors are very vibrant, the contrast and sharpness superb, the facial details and skin tones are life like, you are there, for the most part, as part of the scene.  In some gory lacerations, the anatomic detail can be seen as accurate, and can be bothersome to those unused to it.Several episodes are longer or extended.  It doesn't add more to the spirit of the episodes but mostly prolonging visuals that are shorter on the broadcast version.  There are nicely done popups of Roman history and interesting commentary by the producers, directors, and actors, so you can watch each episode at least twice, first as a show and then as a 'making off' the show.Cons [Minor]AdsDisk 1 is preceded by 10 minutes of advertising of upcoming movies, and they can't be bypassed on my BD player; you can speed play or jump to the next track, but you need to do this 4x before getting to the main menu.  Although they are great eye candy, they are irritating to see over and over again.RestartMy BD player has a 'RESUME' function which plays where you left off a disk, but it works in the PLAY ALL mode or SINGLE PLAY of this disk, not when watching commentaries; if you interrupt a commentary playback, the disk will restart from the start; this could be just my player firmware and not the way the disk software works but this doesn't happen with other disks.The pop ups appear for a fixed time interval, whether they are short quips, or long footnotes.  You have to pause the frame to read the long footnotes and rewinding it to re-read it can be tiring.

reviewText: Based on the Third Seville War, the original Starz series Spartacus: Blood and Sand wonderfully brings to life the legend of Spartacus (Andy Whitfield) and the slave uprising that began in a Capuan ludus owned by Lentulus Batiatus (John Hannah).What makes Spartacus so great is the balance.  For the male audience there is an obscene amount of blood, battle, fighting and killing.  And when swords aren't stabbing organs, the male stars of the show are organ stabbing.  Think of it as a slightly pornographic 300.  Sounds just for the men, right?  Well, rest assured, the women viewers will be pleased both by the ample display of male physique, but also an amazingly complex storyline where women are often the power-brokers.  There really isn't a single character that doesn't have a subplot.The acting is superb in all facets.  Whitfield has sadly passed, but fans of the series will remember him fondly.  Supporting actors provide their talent in heaps.  Alongside Hannah in the Batiatus household is his wife Lucretia, played with a commanding presence by Lucy Lawless.  Manu Bennett is powerful and easily portrays a Gaul warrior capable of defeating numerous opponents in gladiator arenas.  My favorite, however, is Peter Mensah as Doctore.  Mensah is ominous and powerful, a man who must draw stares whenever he enters the room.The one flaw, other than overlookable historical embellishments, is the early series FX that bordered on absurd.  Luckily this waned as the first season progressed, and improved considerably towards the end.  There are times when the language is so over the top it's repetitious and irksome, but for the most part it's engaging.Great sword and sandal (sword and sex?) series, maybe the best overall series on TV.

reviewText: When I got this DVD set I wasn't sure what to expect since I don't watch the cable network Starz, which airs this series. If you don't mind the graphic nature of the series you will probably enjoy this a lot, since it has well-developed characters and drama and the production quality stands up well to what you'd find in a major motion picture. I was pretty impressed with the quality of this series, even though I wouldn't be inclined myself to be a regular viewer of a graphic drama - at least not at this stage in my life. As media has become increasingly graphic, it's not surprising that shows are becoming more edgy in this regard. In some cases the graphic content is there as an authentic depiction of dramas that really occur. Tales with violence, sex, and power struggles can certainly make intriguing drama, and modern productions tend to be more explicit and less implicit in depicting these storylines. However, as a society we may want to consider looking for more prosocial stories to entertain and inspire us. Spartacus fictionally depicts a fairly dark chapter in Western civilization, doing so in a pretty gripping way. It is good entertainment in that sense, though I personally prefer being gripped by films and shows that inspire a vision of a more conscious, harmonious civilization.

reviewText: DON'T form your opinion based on the first episode.  The series starts out like the intro to a teenage boys fantasy of soft-core porn and cartoon violence. But it was interesting watching scenes where, for instance, a husband is having sex with a slave while talking to his wife about political posturing. In terms of the violence, it was interesting how brutal the violence is, but I thought it was cheezy and cartoony the way they did the CGI blood baths.  I know they were trying to be true to the comic, but it doesn't add to the series but rather detracts from it.  So why do it?  I felt like I they were trying to capture the brutality the gladiators live in, but the cartoon-quality softens it to the point sometimes of neutralizing it.  I didn't feel like the violence component was as effective as it could have been.  This is primarily why i didn't give it 5 stars.Some reviewers have criticized the series for having bad acting.  They are simply wrong.  I was surprised about how good the acting was.  I came from a perspective of "this is going to suck" based on the first episode.  It seemed like the series was just a pilot for a video game.  I was thrilled when it became so much more.  The plot is unpredictable, for the most part, people live and die unexpectedly, and motivations of characters often take you by surprise.  There is goodness and badness in all the characters, with a with few exceptions(another reason why it didn't get 5 stars), so you really felt the characters were human even though the execution is somewhat cartoony at times.Overall, worth watching.  It's not as excellent as The Wire, which is possibly the best modern cable series, but it's good.

reviewText: At first I was put off by the relentless splash of CGI goo and guts.  Once I settled in, however, I realized 'Spartacus' was employing that over-the-top visual style of the graphic novel. So I gave it permission to be gross. In return, Spartacus set designers, costumers, DPs and digital artists create an epic feast for the eye.But even the fanciest lighting and graphics can't drive a whole series. The various story threads give us a peek into every layer of Roman society. The writers had a bit of trouble trying to use a Latin language cadence; that structure would occasionally break down or flare up in ways that didn't necessarily map to the situation. Some characters were drawn a little campy/daytime drama, but casting was terrific.  I particularly loved the principal antagonists -- the Sonny & Cher of evildoers -- John Hannah and Lucy Lawless. Another standout was Peter Mensah.  He has a way of commanding every bit of light in the universe for his own purpose (and apparently that purpose was to make me short of breath). It's a real shame that Andy Whitfield couldn't take this role to the end. He smoldered in a way that was infinitely more authentic than Liam McIntyre's rendering. This replacement was along the lines of casting Timothy Dalton/Pierce Brosnan as 007. He's just too chiseled and perfect. Too pretty (only chicks can be both pretty and deadly).For that reason, I'd have to say 'Blood and Sand' and it's prequel 'Gods of the Arena' are perfect sword-n-sandal epics. Subsequent seasons are entertaining enough, but lack much of the passion, scheming and desperation of their predecessors.

reviewText: Visually artistic portrayals of historical figures and events has become something of a national past time in Hollywood since the film 300 became a smashing hit at the box office.  Such films are aesthetically pleasing and genuinely fun to watch but typically lack in historical accuracy in varying degrees.  Then again, such films and television shows are designed to entertain the masses and not necessarily educate- if the viewer wants the reversal then they'd best turn on the History Channel.Spartacus: Blood and Sand falls into the same category as 300 and, to a lesser extent, Pathfinder as both films display impressive visuals while depicting graphic violence and gratuitous sexuality under the guise of being a "historical representation."  Spartacus is a visually stunning miniseries with a compelling plot of deception and lies accompanied by the most violent and sexually graphic depiction than all the Quinton Terrentino films combined and I mean that without any hint of exaggeration.The plot starts simple; an unnamed Thracian leader and officer in the Roman Reserve mutinies against his superiors and goes AWOL, is caught, and later transformed into the legendary gladiator called "Spartacus."  After that, there's deception, promises, broken promises, murder plots, assassinations, sex, complicated love triangles, more sex, and even more sex.  Pretty straight forward.However, despite the carnal simplicity of Spartacus, the story is compelling enough to keep the audience hooked.  Thanks to Spartacus I missed out on a LOT of hours of sleep : not because I kept rewinding during the Lucy Lawless love scenes but because I felt compelled to see how things panned out in the next chapter.  The acting also keeps the audience hooked such as John Hannah, the obnoxious thief of a brother from the Mummy franchise, plays Spartacus' morally devious owner Batiatus that thoroughly convinces the audience that he is one paranoid wannabe elite.While Blood and Sand  was a visually stunning and well acted story, the writers and directing staff took a large amount of creative liberty with the historical accuracy of the time.  As stated in the aforementioned paragraph, the viewer is warned of the graphic nature of the series and justifies it to portray an accurate presentation of the time and culture.  Fair enough given most contemporary war films depict the grotesque nature of war in a similar effort and the violence of Blood and Sand certainly portrays the violent nature of being a gladiator... then again, so did the movie Gladiator.However, the sexualization of the series in an effort to portray Roman society is a gross exaggeration of how things were during that time.  Granted the Roman elite were highly morally promiscuous individuals with sexual appetites that make porn stars blush, there were multiple love triangles within the inner-circles of the senate, and no doubt slave owners grossly abused their "property" sexually.  However, it was generally frowned upon to copulate in open areas as was public nudity.  In certain scenes in the series the audience witnesses many instances of couples having sex (graphically) in public areas when this would have been VERY rare even in ancient Greek society... or, at least, just as rare as it is in any society even in contemporary times.Furthermore, I have to VERY reluctantly ask the question of why do we need to see this?  Yes, as a very typical male I thoroughly enjoyed some of the scenes of extreme carnality and rewound many times, but what is the point?  It doesn't accurately depict anything from that era at all.  If the purpose was to draw in viewers, that's fine, but don't justify it under the false pretense of a "historical representation."Historical inaccuracies do not end there either.  First and foremost, while several aspects of gladiator life seem to be accurate the portrayal of the Roman military is not.  Roman soldiers seen in Blood and Sand are depicted wearing the traditionally known garb that wasn't recorded in use till almost a century later.  There are other nitty gritty historical inaccuracies including names, time-line and continuity errors but another one that really stuck out is that Batiatus is depicted as a politically ambitious character seeking office when such a position was literally above his social status via birth.  If anything, his position was akin to a low-life or, according to some historical circles, a pimp.  I didn't let such inaccuracies bother me much though as I thoroughly enjoyed Blood and Sand, however, it would have helped if they had paid a little more attention to detail since modifying any of the errors would not have significantly affected the plot.All in all, Blood and Sand was truly enjoyable to watch even if the historian in me was screaming in the back of my head.  I would strongly encourage anyone thinking of getting this series to be forewarned that it is extremely graphic and not for the faint of heart or stomach.All in all, an 80% or B-.

Finally, Spartacus and the other gladiators rebel.To say any more would probably give the ending away (even though we know how the Spatacus' revolt ends).There is so much we don't know about Spartacus but names from Roman history at the time are used.  We see Crixus.  He was Spatacus' second in command.  Glaba, a Roman general, who tries to quash the revolt is an important character in the show.  The producers have done quite well in trying to fix up the gaps.Andy Whitfield does a great job playing Spartacus.  The supporting cast also a pretty good job.  Though John Hannah doesn't quite get it right as the bad guy.Despite the problems I have mentioned, Spartacus is well worth a look.

reviewText: I finally got around to watching Spartacus:  Blood and Sand. I was going to start watching it last Fall when I learned of Andy Whitfield's unfortunate passing.  I decided to postpone my review in favor of respecting his passing in case I found that I did not like the series. Sadly, I would learn that we did indeed lose a quite remarkable actor and that my fears of sullying his name were completely unfounded.This paragraph contains minor spoilers as it summarizes the first episode only.  The man who would later be dubbed Spartacus at the very end of the first episode is a Thracian who has agreed to serve the Romans as an auxiliary (although really the advance guard) to the Roman Legion in order to quell a Barbarian threat to the north.  Then, the Romans decide to turn East in order to serve the ego of the Roman leader Glaber (sp?) rather than face the barbarian horde that threatens Spartacus' home.  Outraged, Spartacus refuses to follow their lead, but his followers are a little "overzealous" in their refusal, attacking the Romans.  Spartacus flees from the scene to be reunitied with his wife.  Unfortunately, he is captured and his wife's fate is unknown although he is told that she will be enslaved.  Thereafter, Spartacus is thrown into the arena to face certain death only to emerge victorious...and thus begins his tale.Andy Whitfield, while easy on the eye which might otherwise drip acting poison, is an extremely good actor being able to convey a mix of emotions quite well through facial expression alone and his tone conveys a depth of sincerity.  Every emotion that he experiences, I immediately empathize with; I truly believe that we lost a man who could have easily been an Oscar-contender.  Craig Parker plays Glaber and if his face looks familiar, it's because he actually plays an elf in Lord Of The Rings (Fellowship and then Two Towers where he leads the ill-fated contingent of elves sent to help at Helms Deep).  When I heard Lucy Lawless was in this series, I was worried that the whole series may come across as a campy farce, but she actually does quite well as the wife of the man who would eventually purchase Spartacus as a gladiator, Baitatus.  Baritatus is played by John Hannah and I'm still having a hard time erasing his role in The Mummy movies from my memory.  He does quite well, however.Spartacus:  Blood and Sand is visually striking, but the CGI is a little heavy-handed at times.  It comes across as a poor man's "300" and sometimes it works and other times there is too much blood being sprayed for someone to have feasibly suffered just to pick himself up and keep fighting.  Backgrounds suffer the same, see-sawing from looking decent to looking too obviously CGI to be simply stylish.  That said, it doesn't detract from the overall experience - it's just occasionally distracting, that's all.One word of note - it earns a Mature rating for a good reason.  The first episode alone has plenty of violence and sexuality throughout.  Buyer be warned - this is definitely NOT a light treatment of the subject material and Starz holds very little back.I definitely think that Spartacus is worth investing time to watch.
summary: Visually striking, yet occasionally distracting, Spartacus leaves a mark...

reviewText: When "Spartacus - Blood and Sand" first appeared on Starz I was hoping for at the very least a minor "Rome" rip-off. So enamored of the HBO series I was hungry for more drama, intrigue, sex and blood in the Republican era of ancient Rome that I reluctantly decided to give "Spartacus" a chance.The first episode was for me a bit of a snooze and heavily influenced by "300" in it's dark visual style. But I did find the performances arresting enough to give episode two a go. That is when "Spartacus" takes off and soars to bloody glory. The story grabs you by the gut leading you on into a world of high drama, sex, murder, lust, greed, sadism, that is both thrilling and mind-blowing. If you ever wondered if you could actually watch a gladiatorial contest, this is the test for you! Visceral, bloody splendor unfolds in the arena of Capua. If you have a weak stomach then you are in for some cinematic cgi shocks! I found the whole thing thrilling but many times I had to shut my eyes to the on screen gore. Long gone are the days of showing just the top of Pompey's severed head as in "Cleopatra" (1963) in an olive amphora. Now the severed heads go flying though the air spurting gallons of blood.But the real treasure in Spartacus is found in the interesting writing that challenges and often elevates the story to a poetic, moving and often comedic brilliance. Sharp witty, repartee in a pseudo kind of Latin meets Shakespeare shows how varied and multi leveled our English language can be.Then there are the performances by the cast. Andy Whitfield as the hero of the slave rebellion is magnificent. A real find for the show and brings a sexy gravitas to the proceedings. John Hannah as Batiatus takes the bull by the horns and holds nothing back in his bold and fun portrait of the owner of the Lunista. Gladiatorial nemesis and blood brother to Spartacus is Crixus played by Manu Bennett. A hunk who can act the hell out of this part. He is a joy to watch as he battles for his forbidden love entangled in the midst of a demanding mistress' lust. As the spoilt Ilithyia wife to the man who brought Spartacus to his fate as a gladiator the marvelous Viva Bianca is immensely wicked and immensely fun to watch. Then there is the best surprise of the entire show, Lucy Lawless as Lucretia wife of Batiatus and domina of the Lunista. This cunning, conniving, depraved, wicked, intelligent woman of the first century B.C. is the roll of a lifetime for Miss Lawless. She is magnificent, and splendoriforus in the part. A real treat that is the cherry on the top of the Roman feast that is "Spartacus - Blood and Sand".

reviewText: This series combines the visual style of 300, the general subject matter of Gladiator, and an attempt to meet the historical drama of Rome.The film 300 contained much of the same hypermasculine horse poo, the nonsensical pairing of cruelty with honor and individualism without concern for historical accuracy.  The visuals here, especially in the fight scenes are a direct borrowing, both in terms of their highly digitized manipulation and their stop-action/ fake blood spurting.The weak spot in this series, other than its not really treading any new ground, is the script.  Specifically, the dialogue is ham-handed.  The lines veer from dull over-written language meant to sound archaic, if one presumes that people walked around speaking in elevated pronouncements, and pointless, frequent vulgarity.  It makes the series seem cheap.  The actors do the best with what they have.That's not to say that no one will enjoy it.If you like to look at muscly men throwing each other around or sitting around looking oily, you will probably like this show, since that's what most scenes consist of.If you like your women without personalities (other than vampy cattiness), either naked or victimized or both, but never as interesting as real women in history, then this is the show for you.If you miss the softcore porn of the 1970's or of romantic historical fiction, the sensibilities of this series will probably appeal to you.The hard work of the cast and crew involved is somewhat misused since the creators' primary interest is to wallow in the toilet of the subconscious.

reviewText: As a fan of the Krik Douglas Spartacus I didn't know what to expect of this modern series.Its stop-action sequences, fake blood and gore distracted me from the story, but as the series continued I became accustomed to it and it stopped bothering me.The series grew on me, and I found myself enjoying it more and more. Yes, it's violent and gritty. But it illustrates the age in a way I've never seen before, and although one always has to question historical accuracy in entertainment, it brought a new perspective to the era. It's also a vivid reminder of how lucky we are to live in modern times, in a wealthy country with a wide range of freedoms.The star is knocked off for themes that, though perhaps closer to reality, I do not enjoy watching -- the excess of blood and gore and R-rated (some argue X-rated) material.One thing I really liked was the DVD case, which for 4 discs is slim and convenient. The graphics are impressive. The format of the case is like a book, with a hard cover. Each disc is inside a slip on its own page, each page with a beautiful colorful picture and a list of the disc contents.I am glad not to have to deal with stubborn plastic holders and bits of broken plastic, though I worry the discs may scratch on removing/replacing.Here is a list of the disc contents as shown on the DVD pages:Disc 1:Episode 1, The Red SerpentEpisode 2, Sacramentum GladiatorumEpisode 3, LegendsEpisode 4, The Thing in the PitDisc 2:Episode 5, Shadow GamesEpisode 6, Delicate ThingsEpisode 7, Great and Unfortunate ThingsEpisode 8, Mark of the BrotherhoodDisc 3:Episode 9, WhoreEpisode 10, Party FavorsEpisode 11, Old WoundsEpisode 12, RevelationDisc 4:Episode 13, Kill Them AllBonus Features:Audio CommentarySpartacus: Blood and Sand, Behind the ScenesSpartacus: Battle RoyaleGladiator Boot CampCrime and PunishmentAndy Gets PlasteredLegend Re-ImaginedOh, Those Randy RomansShooting Green: The Shadow of DeathExposing Your LudusThe last 'page' of the case lists the episode credits, so you know who wrote the good episodes, and who to blame for the mediocre ones.Spartacus kept me interested to the end. I'm even looking forward to the next season.

reviewText: Since I consider myself an educated, civilized being, I was strongly tempted to give this series only two stars because of the unimaginative - and mostly unnecessary - profanity its characters constantly excrete and because of the equally unimaginative gladiator training and fighting sequences (which take up time that would have been better spent telling us more about the characters, especially the gladiators: where do they all come from and how did they end up as slaves in Batiatus' ludus?), accompanied by a metal-laden soundtrack, which seems to be inevitable in historic action flicks these days.A brief Web search showed that not much is known about Spartacus, but it appears that the series' producers took care to incorporate actual historical figures, such as Glaber, Batiatius, Crixus and Oenomaus, to name a few. It also made an attempt to get the scenery and costumes halfway right (although many of the women's dresses seemed straight from the pages of a fantasy magazine - but I'm no expert on Roman fashion).Unlike other reviewers, I had no problem with the abundant sex scenes (with the exception of those in which the actors looked decidedly uncomfortable, like Braca's [cringe-worthy!] kissing scenes). Rather than trying to shock viewers or point out the lewdness and lasciviousness of the Romans, they simply seemed to state the fact that people who live in a world of many uncertainties, where human lives count little and are constantly lost to hunger, disease, crime, and other dangers, enjoy whatever distractions and pleasures they can have, whenever and wherever they can get them.I very much enjoyed Lucy Lawless' Lucretia (although I found the chemistry between her and John Hannah non-existent - the man seemed mostly full of himself and preoccupied with the c- and f-words), Viva Bianca's Ilithyia (although I couldn't help thinking "Haldir! You are most welcome!" every time her husband Glaber appeared on screen), and Jaime Murray's Gaia in "Gods of the Arena". The actors portraying the gladiators do passable jobs, even though their roles consist mostly of strutting about, looking buff. At that they all excel, and I forgive them their sometimes wooden dialogue performances because they are such eye candy.Having never watched "Rome", this series was new and different to me, and thanks to "Gods of the Arena", I now also know what a gomph stick is. Overall, I felt well entertained - although the next time I'm in the mood for a good, earnest fight scene, I'll rather dig out a Bruce Lee movie. :)

reviewText: I doubt there's much I can add to the other 400-odd reviews here, so I'm just going to summarize my own observations after the second round of viewing.Says Wikipedia, little is known about the real-life Spartacus before the massive slave revolt that he led ca. 70 BCE.  This series is an attempt to fill in those gaps; a fictionalized account of Spartacus's capture and enslavement by the Romans, and the events leading up to that revolt.And. It. ROCKS.The good: DeKnight and co. hit this one out of the park.  The storyline is complex, subtle, exciting, and utterly believable - I suspect they came closer to capturing the true flavor of life in the late Roman Republic than even they thought they did.  All the leads - Andy Whitfield, John Hannah, and Lucy Lawless in particular - are amazing.  The extensive CGI is rough in spots, but ambitious and imaginative for series TV - on occasion they actually use the over-the-top blood and gore to artistic effect.  The camera work is wonderful; among the best I've seen on television.  I've watched the series twice through now, including the first run on Starz, and I honestly can't point to a single weak episode.  Everyone involved with this show clearly put their hearts into it, and it shows.The bad, if you want to call it that: Okay folks, listen carefully.  Pay close attention.  Read this, and believe it: ** THIS SHOW IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. **  This is EASILY the most explicitly sexy and hyper-violent thing I have ever seen on television.  Even considering the subject matter the blood and gore are retina-searing, in fact SO overdone and over-the-top at times as to short out one's suspension of disbelief...which is probably a good thing.  If you're the faint-at-the-sight-of-blood sort, keep smelling salts and barf bags handy.  As to the "sexy" part, we're talking full frontal for both men and women, and when the twain meet (frequently) the result is often outright soft porn.The good news here is that very little of the generous nudity and the uncountable gallons of digital blood are gratuitous; the TV-MA material is almost always natural and integral to the plot.The ugly: Sadly, Andy Whitfield had to leave the series due to an ongoing battle with non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  (*UPDATE* A battle which, sadly, he lost on 9/11/11. RIP.)  The role of Spartacus has been recast, and the prequel mini-seriesSpartacus: Gods of the Arenaturned out to be a worthy successor (predecessor?) despite Whitfield's absence, so I have high hopes for future episodes.In short, if you have any interest at all in historical fiction and you can handle the adult-oriented material, this is a must-see.  Five stars, unreservedly; eagerly awaiting more.
summary: Outstanding storytelling, but not for everyone

reviewText: Wow!  Riveting entertainment with some technical imperfections.  Many of the special effects are pretty obvious and the producers' decision to use an abundance of splashing 'blood' was a mistake.  Some sex is useful in the development of a story about ancient Capua and its major gladiatorial school but, in the case of 'Spartacus', its excess use verges on the gratuitous.  A comparison with the excellent--and also highly sexualized--HBO series 'Rome' is unavoidable and, overall, 'Rome' seems to be the more expensive and historically accurate production.Nevertheless, the above criticisms are relatively minor when compared against the pure movement, excitement and color that is 'Spartacus'.  The acting is very good and the plots excellent.  The writers take us on a tortuous journey characterized by deceit, murder and jockeying for power.  The gladiators are, in a sense, pawns in this very Roman struggle.  Their lives and deaths are to honor their Ludus and elevate the House of Batiatus.  The gladiators, themselves, go through a ruthless winnowing process.  Those who survive may become great champions of the arena with egos that swell to the near bursting point.  For many of these men, champion status is literally more important than life itself and, amazing as it may seem to us today, gladiator-slaves become sports' heroes the likes of which the world has never seen before or since.At the same time, 'Spartacus' let's us into the pain and privation of people who have been ripped from their private lives and sold into slavery--people who are no longer people.  Perhaps this is the point of some of the sex scenes.  Many of the women depicted are slaves ordered to service gladiators and others.  Much like the gladiators, who have little control over their quivering lives, female slaves don't have control of even their bodies.The gladiator/actors used in this film don't closely resemble the known biotypes of actual gladiators.  The actors seem to have undergone a bodybuilding regime producing low body fat and rippling muscles.  Actual gladiators--to judge by ancient drawings--seem to have been bulkier men with thicker waists.  My guess is that gladiator training was very different from bodybuilding and, not remarkably, the aim was quite different.  Strength and stamina would have been important, of course, but some body fat may, in fact, have not only increased stamina but may have actually added some marginal wound protection.

reviewText: As someone who enjoyed the movie300 [Blu-ray] I have to confess I was puzzled when I first watched the trailers for this series. It is supposed to be a retelling of the story of Spartacus with lots of liberties taken to fill in the historical gaps prior to becoming the infamous rebel we know from history and other adaptations. The visual style is pretty similar to the one Zack Snyder used in his adaptation of Frank Miller story.Many reviewers have compared these two as the visual style is similar, but 'Spartacus: Blood and Sand' also borrows from movies likeGladiator (Sapphire Series) [Blu-ray] and other TV shows such asRome: The Complete Series [Blu-ray]. As a huge fan of both 'Gladiator' and 'Rome' I could not help to compare them with each other.Another thing to keep in mind is that this is not material suitable for younger audiences, there is plenty of violence (very graphical), and a lot of gratuitous nudity and sex. While its presence may obey historical reasons,  much of the nudity feels not necessary as opposed, for example to the one displayed in 'Rome', in which those situations had a purpose or were relevant to the characters and their stories. Here you will have plenty of this type of material even in the backgrounds or among the audience in the gladiator arenas.All things considered, 'Blood and Sand' ended up being quite entertaining, the characters and their motivations made a great story to follow, filled treachery and  corruption; the character development was also great save for one character in the final episode of the season (Crixus, one of the best of the season in my opinion) Peter Mensah, who portrayed the messenger thrown to the pit in '300', also does a great job in portraying Doctore, the trainer of gladiators. The highlight would probably be Andy Whitfield in the role of Spartacus, it is hard to imagine how will season 2 end up without him (he had to abandon the show due to health reasons)The audio and video quality in the DVD presentation sound and look great upscaled to HD, this will definitely be worth to own in Bluray if you like the story and the visuals. The fact that the DVD looks as detailed as it does can only mean the BD should look as reference material.Additionally, the last disc of the set includes several extras, one of them being an audio commentary on last episode 'Kill them all' Documentaries that can be found in the final disc include:Behind the scenesSpartacus: Battle RoyaleGladiator boot campCrime and punishmentAndy gets plasteredLegen re-imaginedOh, those Randy RomansShooting green: The shadow of deathExposing your ludusBottom line, if you enjoyed the above referenced movies and TV shows, you are in for a treat!

reviewText: Spartacus: Blood & Sand - Season 1 is about the slave who became Rome's most notorious rebel leader.In this version, a Thracian who loves his wife greatly goes off to war for Rome. When it becomes clear that they are not going where they thought, he and the other Thracians desert.Not a good idea as the commander of that Roman garrison finds he and his wife after a night of reunion love and Claudius Glaber rips the young virile Thracian from his warm pallet and wife's arms. Young Thracian guy gets carted off to be meat for the arena while the wife is sold off to slavery.When said young Thracian snaps at the arena and slaughters the four beastmen who were to execute him, he is dubbed Spartacus by the man who buys him. Batiatus, his new owner, has a stable of gladiators. It is a family business. It is there that Spartacus will learn to fight and eventually despise his Roman masters.As this series was filmed in New Zealand, the lead is an Australian actor named Andy Whitfield. He is lean and handsome and has an Australian accent. A lot of the actors have Australian accents. Except John Hannah (of The Mummy fame) who has a Scottish accent. I'm used these B-list series having American accents so the Australian is kind of refreshing.There is a lot of sex in the series. Spartacus and his wife. Batiatus and his wife, Lucretia. Lucretia and the top gladiator, Crixus. So on and so forth. But hey, it is Rome. Sex is expected.What was surprising was the gore porn. Yes, I know. This is about gladiators. But the way the filmmakers lingered on the violence really did make me go, "This is like porn except violence is the replacement of sex." Slow-mo shots of smashed faces, cut throats, and gushing blood are a-plenty.Now I like my violence in movies and non-network television as much as the next American consumer, but this was a lot. There are at least 3 episodes that I couldn't get through. I made it through the last episode but I was also sleepy so maybe I was too tired to remember how gory it was.There are some things I did like. I really liked the subplot of Crixus and Navia. Both are slaves and while Crixus is a brute of a man, he is made tender, if clumsy, in Navia's presence.But even for the elements I liked, it was so unrelentingly bloody that it was hard to focus on anything else.I had to give it 3-stars. For viewers who like their gore to the nth degree and beyond, this is the series for you.For the rest of us, it is probably good to pass.

reviewText: "Spartacus:  Blood and Sand" plumbs the depths of shamelessness in its hunt for an audience.  It steals its broad storyline from the demi-classic Stanley Kubrick film.  It steals its visual effects - gallons of blood and comic-book violence - from Zack Snyder's adapation of Frank Miller's "300."  It steals its proud dedication to T&A; from soft core porn.  And it steals its stilted dialogue and declarative voice from the lesser chapters of Tolkien's "The Silmarillion."And yet, the darn thing grows on you.Perhaps it's the game cast.  Andy Whitfield, who could ably serve as Brad Pitt's body double, takes on the title role with a certain wooden-headed gusto.  John Hannah throws himself into his role as Batiatus, owner of Spartacus's gladiator school, with all the oily charm he can muster - and that's saying a lot.  Watching Hannah, among the most charming and endearing of actors, sink into depravity like a snake is a rare treat.  Lucy Lawless - yes, the warrior princess - embodies the plotting Roman spouse as Batiatus's clever wife Lucretia.  These two attempt to out-Nero Nero as they drink and love while plotting and murdering their way up the social scale.The other gladiators are a chiseled bunch of lunkheads, given to much snarling and flexing whilst covered in gleaming oil.  The physiques and the acting are both worthy of an NFL locker room.  But these gladiators are so obviously gladiators that we stop expecting this to be another PBS production of "I, Claudius" and instead lower our expectations to see what these MMA refugees can do.Ultimatley, once you accept "Spartacus:  Blood and Sand" for what it is - an R-rated comic book aiming for low pulp rather than high art - it becomes entertaining.  Sure, you may hide your copy your boxed set of "The Wire" or the colleted films of Akira Kurosawa when the parents come visit or if you have the pastor over for dinner.  But you'll also find an excuse to watch more often than you might think.
summary: Bad writing, a style stolen from "300," but a game cast make "Spartacus" watchable

reviewText: WIth complex storylines, vivid characters and lusty performances, Spartacus is enjoyable adult entertainment. It feels to me like an NC-7 rated version of Ridley Scott's Gladiator.Andy Whitfield is striking as the stoic and sexy lead character. The recent news that he has had to drop out of future production due to poor health is sad on many levels. Please keep him in your thought and prayers for a speedy recovery.It's great fun to see Lacy Lawless back on the small screen. She was an exciting campy wonder as Xena, but here she shows her real acting chops, and she's terrific. The whole cast is a revelation - how they find so many talented actors, who play so well together, is beyond me.The production values are insanely impressive for a TV show. While some of the green screen work is a little obvious, the vast majority is compelling and believable enough that it creates an immersive world.  Meanwhile, other set pieces like costumes and props are more subtle but equally impressive. I hope the production crew gets the recognition they deserve for their painstakingly detailed work.The two things that I'd like to see less of on the series are the gratuitous nudity and cartoonishly excessively amounts of blood. Not that I'm a prude by any means, but both tend to take me out of the story. At times, these elements feel tacked on, as if there's a quota for how much flesh and plasma each episode must display. The nudity bothers me less than the gore - the show takes place in a lusty world where the human body is both celebrated and exploited. But I don't understand the artistic decision to so excessively animate fountains of blood and severed limbs.  When scenes of battle and torture are depicted as slo-mo abstractions of wildly exaggerated red blooms, beautifully grotesque, I'm not sure what the producers are saying about the violence, or what it's supposed to make us feel. For me, the self-concious special effects just call attention to themselves while distracting from the narrative.Other than those two quibbles, this is a wonderfully acted, impressively produced show that is most moving in its quietest moments. It's a wonder to me that entertainment of this caliber is produced for TV.

reviewText: First, if you're already a fan of this series on Starz, and just looking for a review of the DVD release - well, it's excellent.  Beautifully packaged, good transfer - not much else to say.As for the series itself: it's really a modern interpretation of the 70s exploitation genre, set in ancient Rome - "Gladiator" meets grindhouse, as I tag it above.  You know what you're in for in the first few minutes of the first episode, when a fight scene goes into slow-motion except for the blood spatter, which is accelerated relative to the rest of the action.  There are buckets and spigots and splatters galore throughout, plus a lot of nudity of course, so you'll like it if you're into that sort of thing.  Just be warned, this is a lot closer to "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" than it is to "I, Claudius" or even to "Rome."Apart from the blood, there's a lot more going on here visually.  The colors are oversaturated, there's a lot of comic-book-like editing and special effects, like the CGI backgrounds others have mentioned.  The director's favorite move is to freeze a character's face in one setting and morph to the same face in a different setting.  It's similar in principle to a traditional visual vocabulary for flashback/flashforward, but the feel is much different from other approaches I've seen; personally I'm not sure it really works, but it is interesting, I'll give it that.The writing, and the acting for that matter, is melodramatic and cliched, but that too is appropriate to the genre - meaning of course the grindhouse/exploitation genre, not the period drama.Finally - just to state the obvious - this series has nothing to do with the Stanley Kubrick / Kirk Douglas movie.  Which is a classic, of course, but in an entirely different genre.

reviewText: Starz' series Sparatcus Season 1 takes place before the events so famously portrayed by Kirk Douglas some 50 years ago inSpartacus - Criterion Collection. Season one takes place almost entirely in the ludus (Gladiator training school) where Spartacus was taken for his refusal to continue following a particularly argonant and incompetent roman general.  Amazingly, all of season 1 sets the background and builds the character for Spartacus.  Season 1 develops the motivation for the leader of the greatest slave revolt in antiquity.Some have mentioned this series immediate ancestors: HBO'sRome: The Complete Series [Blu-ray] and300: The Complete Experience (Blu-ray Book and BD-Live).  This seems to be a fairly accurate reference point. Spartacus has plenty of the conniving Roman family politics (and sex) that we loved in HBO's Rome.  And Spartacus contains plenty of stylized blood that echoes from 300.  However, Spartacus stands well on its own.The stylized blood lends itself well to arena combat.  And the writers and producers of Spartacus did their homework: just as Romans had innumerable combinations of Gladiatorial combat, so too does Season 1 show an incredible array of warriors fighting with weapons, teams, and solo.  The stylized bloodletting lends itself well to the "spectacle" of Roman gladiatorial games.The actors are brilliant in this series.  Spartacus' characters in all their humanity and politicing, and fighting, makes the whole transcend both the blood and sex of the show.  The plot is tightly written, which makes the series fantastic to own on DVD/blu-ray.  Waiting from week to week at the end of each cliff-hanger episode would have been torture.While Kirk Douglas' Spartacus was superb in its own right, Andy Whitfield's Spartacus seems so much more completely human.  Andy Whitfield plays a Spartacus who is tortured and torn while also displaying love wisdom and cunning when needed.The real comparison will be when Spartacus Season 2 is released.  Whitfield will be reprising many of the events from Kubrick's film.The Blu-ray edition also has MovieIQ which details the actors and some notes on scenes throughout each episode.

reviewText: After a bit of cheese and a few cliches, this series really takes off. I was put off a bit watching the first episode (the pilot), especially when Spartacus takes a piece of leather and asks his wife to keep it close to her thighs to remember him by. But after that it gets much, much better. We've finally got a new cinematic technique; I've been waiting for a new one since the slow-mo-speed-up of Matrix (this went so far as Watchmen, even, for goodness's sake); the film technique here is interesting in that you often see a character moving through space and the background scrolls the movement of time. King of neat stuff for a viewer. It's a difference, at least, that matters as you're watching. (It loses a bit in the retelling.) These stories are very sexy, very bloody, including nudity. It's not for the kiddies, but it's the best of the new HBO-Home-Theater-esque TV serial. By the second or third episode, I was captivated in spite of myself. Good stuff.

This is an unfortunate by-product of BD-Java. Some Blu Ray is encoded as BD-Java and some is not. I like to be able to stop and then start at the same point on a disk again without the hassle of going through previews, warning screens and menus to find where I left off. Consequently I always avoid any BD which is BD-Java. The DVD is up-converted to 1080p anyway by my player and looks almost as good as the Blu-Ray -- without the annoyances. Great series but beware of the Blu-Ray Java inconvenience.
